item.title: A Total Eclipse Will Sweep The U.S. In August, And People Are Going Nuts For It
item.description: June 30, 2017 - NASA says a partial eclipse will be visible throughout the country. But within a "path of totality" from Oregon to South Carolina, an eclipse industry is booming.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 30, 2017 - NASA says a partial eclipse will be visible throughout the country. But within a "path of totality" from Oregon to South Carolina, an eclipse industry is booming. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/06/30/535048940/a-total-eclipse-will-sweep-the-u-s-in-august-and-people-are-going-nuts-for-it

item.title: Meet The Indiana Jones Of Ancient Ales And Extreme Beverages
item.description: June 30, 2017 - Patrick McGovern searches for and studies the residues of fermented drinks that can be thousands of years old — and then re-creates them. His new book explores these brews and their cultural value.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 30, 2017 - Patrick McGovern searches for and studies the residues of fermented drinks that can be thousands of years old — and then re-creates them. His new book explores these brews and their cultural value. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/06/30/532959384/meet-the-indiana-jones-of-ancient-ales-and-extreme-beverages

item.title: Pesticides Are Harming Bees — But Not Everywhere, Major New Study Shows
item.description: June 29, 2017 - A huge new study conducted in 33 sites across Europe finds that seeds coated with neonicotinoid pesticides harm bees living nearby. The damage, though, depends on local conditions.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - A huge new study conducted in 33 sites across Europe finds that seeds coated with neonicotinoid pesticides harm bees living nearby. The damage, though, depends on local conditions. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/06/29/534852611/pesticides-are-harming-bees-but-not-everywhere-major-new-study-shows

item.title: Maryland Farmer Fights To Keep Chesapeake Bay Cleanup Alive
item.description: June 29, 2017 - The Chesapeake Bay cleanup depends heavily on farmers taking steps to keep runoff from entering the bay. But the Environmental Protection Agency's plan to help them do it has been controversial. NPR's Ari Shapiro talks to one Maryland farmer who changed his mind about the EPA efforts to clean up the bay.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - The Chesapeake Bay cleanup depends heavily on farmers taking steps to keep runoff from entering the bay. But the Environmental Protection Agency's plan to help them do it has been controversial. NPR's Ari Shapiro talks to one Maryland farmer who changed his mind about the EPA efforts to clean up the bay. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534916087/maryland-farmer-fights-to-keep-chesapeake-bay-cleanup-alive

item.title: Researchers Analyze Economic Impact Of Climate Change In The U.S.
item.description: June 29, 2017 - A team of scientists and economists claims they've come up with the most thorough analysis of the cost of climate change in the U.S. Most of the country will suffer economic loss in addition to higher mortality from heat waves and loss of agriculture productivity by 2100. But like all predictions far into the future, this one has a wide range of outcomes and could be overshadowed by new technology still to be invented.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - A team of scientists and economists claims they've come up with the most thorough analysis of the cost of climate change in the U.S. Most of the country will suffer economic loss in addition to higher mortality from heat waves and loss of agriculture productivity by 2100. But like all predictions far into the future, this one has a wide range of outcomes and could be overshadowed by new technology still to be invented. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534916108/researchers-analyze-economic-impact-of-climate-change-in-the-u-s

item.title: The Plague Is Back, This Time In New Mexico
item.description: June 29, 2017 - In medieval times, they called it "the black death." It's still around, routinely cropping up in the U.S. This time, the New Mexico Department of Health reports three cases.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - In medieval times, they called it "the black death." It's still around, routinely cropping up in the U.S. This time, the New Mexico Department of Health reports three cases. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/06/29/534863486/the-bubonic-plague-is-back-this-time-in-new-mexico

item.title: Mapping The Potential Economic Effects Of Climate Change
item.description: June 29, 2017 - Scientists and economists predict what parts of the U.S. may get hit hardest by climate change. A new study goes county by county to gauge the potential cost of global warming.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - Scientists and economists predict what parts of the U.S. may get hit hardest by climate change. A new study goes county by county to gauge the potential cost of global warming. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/06/29/534896130/mapping-the-potential-economic-effects-of-climate-change

item.title: C. Diff Infections Are Falling, Thanks To Better Cleaning And Fewer Antibiotics
item.description: June 29, 2017 - The bacterium C. difficile causes one of the most common infections in hospitals and nursing homes. After climbing for decades, the rate of new infections is now falling.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - The bacterium C. difficile causes one of the most common infections in hospitals and nursing homes. After climbing for decades, the rate of new infections is now falling. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/29/534870581/c-diff-infections-are-falling-thanks-to-better-cleaning-and-fewer-antibiotics

item.title: 'Sea Pickles' Wash Ashore In Pacific Northwest
item.description: June 29, 2017 - Unicorns of the sea or sea pickles. Whatever you call them, pyrosomes are suddenly making life hard on the Pacific coast of the U.S. and Canada. Rachel Martin and Steve Inskeep explain.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - Unicorns of the sea or sea pickles. Whatever you call them, pyrosomes are suddenly making life hard on the Pacific coast of the U.S. and Canada. Rachel Martin and Steve Inskeep explain. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534835129/sea-pickles-wash-ashore-in-pacific-northwest

item.title: Boaty McBoatface Makes Its Triumphant Return, Hauling 'Unprecedented Data'
item.description: June 28, 2017 - The curiously named submersible wrapped up its inaugural voyage last week. And, as the British Antarctic Survey noted Wednesday, Boaty acquitted itself well on the seven-week expedition.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 28, 2017 - The curiously named submersible wrapped up its inaugural voyage last week. item.title: Chesapeake Bay Dead Zones Are Fading, But Proposed EPA Cuts Threaten Success
item.description: June 28, 2017 - After years of failed attempts at cleaning up the dead zones, the Chesapeake Bay, once a national disgrace, is teeming with wildlife again. But success is fragile, and it might be even more so now.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 28, 2017 - After years of failed attempts at cleaning up the dead zones, the Chesapeake Bay, once a national disgrace, is teeming with wildlife again. item.title: New Island Surfaces Along Coast Of North Carolina's Outer Banks
item.description: June 28, 2017 - There's a new island off the coast of North Carolina. Dave Hallac, Superintendent of Cape Hatteras National Seashore, tells NPR's Robert Siegel about it.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 28, 2017 - There's a new island off the coast of North Carolina. Dave Hallac, Superintendent of Cape Hatteras National Seashore, tells NPR's Robert Siegel about it. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/28/534764979/new-island-surfaces-along-coast-of-north-carolinas-outer-banks

item.title: U.S. Air Pollution Still Kills Thousands Every Year, Study Concludes
item.description: June 28, 2017 - An analysis examining mortality among millions of Americans concludes that a tiny decrease in levels of soot could save about 12,000 lives each year.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 28, 2017 - An analysis examining mortality among millions of Americans concludes that a tiny decrease in levels of soot could save about 12,000 lives each year. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/28/534594373/u-s-air-pollution-still-kills-thousands-every-year-study-concludes

item.title: Child Care Centers Often Don't Hire The Most Qualified Teachers, Study Shows
item.description: June 28, 2017 - Child care centers don't necessarily hire the most qualified teachers. A new study shows that child care centers pick applicants who are in the middle of the pack.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 28, 2017 - Child care centers don't necessarily hire the most qualified teachers. A new study shows that child care centers pick applicants who are in the middle of the pack. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/28/534671504/child-care-centers-often-dont-hire-the-most-qualified-teachers-study-shows

item.title: This GOP Health Bill Proposes New Limits To Medical Malpractice Awards
item.description: June 28, 2017 - The bill H.R. 1215 would limit awards for non-economic damages — such as pain and suffering — to $250,000. President Trump supports the bill, but many others across the political spectrum don't.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
